title: Enstrophy
text:
In <a href="fluid%20dynamics">fluid dynamics</a>, the enstrophy can be interpreted as another type of <a href="potential%20density">potential density</a>; or, more concretely, the quantity directly related to the <a href="kinetic%20energy">kinetic energy</a> in the flow model that corresponds to <a href="dissipation">dissipation</a> effects in the fluid. It is particularly useful in the study of <a href="turbulence">turbulent flows</a>, and is often identified in the study of <a href="Electrostatic%20ion%20thruster">thruster</a>s as well as the field of <a href="combustion">combustion</a> theory.
Given a domain formula_1 and a once-weakly differentiable vector field formula_2 which represents a fluid flow, such as a solution to the <a href="Navier%E2%80%93Stokes%20equations">Navier-Stokes equations</a>, its enstrophy is given by:
formula_3
where formula_4. This quantity is the same as the squared <a href="seminorm">seminorm</a> formula_5of the solution in the <a href="Sobolev%20space">Sobolev space</a> formula_6. 
In the case that the flow is <a href="Incompressible%20flow">incompressible</a>, or equivalently that formula_7, the enstrophy can be described as the integral of the square of the <a href="vorticity">vorticity</a> formula_8,
or, in terms of the <a href="flow%20velocity">flow velocity</a>,
formula_10
In the context of the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations, enstrophy appears in the following useful result
formula_11
The quantity in parentheses on the left is the energy in the flow, so the result says that energy declines proportional to the <a href="Viscosity">kinematic viscosity</a> formula_12 times the enstrophy.
